description: During the Battle of Marineford, Squard - one of Whitebeard's allied pirate captains - shockingly stabs Whitebeard after being manipulated by Admiral Akainu. Despite the betrayal, Whitebeard forgives Squard and rallies his forces by breaking through the Marine's encircling ice walls.

events.title: Squard's Tragic Past Revealed
events.description: Squard's backstory is revealed through flashback, showing how his entire crew was killed by Gol D. Roger years ago. Whitebeard took in Squard after this devastating loss, giving him a new family and purpose.
events.significance: Establishes Squard's deep-seated hatred for Roger and explains why Akainu's manipulation was so effective, as he exploited Squard's trauma.

quotes.speaker: Squard
quotes.context: Squard explains his hatred for Roger to Whitebeard

events.title: Akainu Reveals Ace is Roger's Son to Squard
events.description: Admiral Akainu reveals to Squard that Ace is the son of Gol D. Roger, weaponizing this information to manipulate Squard. Akainu claims Whitebeard made a secret deal with the Marines to save Ace and his crew while sacrificing the allied pirate captains.
events.significance: This revelation is the key to Akainu's manipulation strategy, exploiting Squard's hatred of Roger and creating doubt about Whitebeard's loyalty to his allies.

quotes.text: Ace is the son of Gol D. Roger!
quotes.speaker: Akainu
quotes.context: Akainu reveals Ace's parentage to Squard as part of his manipulation

events.title: Squard Stabs Whitebeard
events.description: Believing Akainu's lies about Whitebeard's betrayal, Squard approaches Whitebeard and violently stabs him through the chest with his sword. Both pirates and Marines are shocked by this act of betrayal from one of Whitebeard's own allies.
events.significance: This is one of the most shocking moments in the Marineford War, demonstrating the effectiveness of Akainu's psychological warfare and severely wounding the world's strongest man.

quotes.text: You have thrust a sword into your father's body!
quotes.speaker: Whitebeard
quotes.context: Whitebeard's initial response to Squard's betrayal

events.title: Battle Comes to a Halt
events.description: The entire battlefield freezes in shock as Squard's betrayal is witnessed by both the pirate forces and the Marines. Fighting temporarily stops as everyone processes what just happened.
events.significance: Shows the magnitude of Squard's action and how it affected morale on both sides of the war.

events.title: Whitebeard's Forgiveness
events.description: Despite being stabbed, Whitebeard doesn't retaliate against Squard. Instead, he hugs him and calls him a 'foolish son,' explaining that he was manipulated by Akainu. Whitebeard declares that a child should not bear the sins of their father, referring to Ace.
events.significance: This moment epitomizes Whitebeard's character as a father figure who loves his 'sons' unconditionally. It's one of the most emotionally powerful scenes in the series, showing true forgiveness and leadership.

quotes.text: You are a foolish son... but I still love you.
quotes.speaker: Whitebeard
quotes.context: Whitebeard forgives Squard for stabbing him

quotes.text: It's ridiculous to pin the blame on a child for the sins of a father.
quotes.speaker: Whitebeard
quotes.context: Whitebeard defending Ace from being blamed for Roger's actions

events.title: Whitebeard Acknowledges Sengoku's Strategy
events.description: Whitebeard recognizes and praises Fleet Admiral Sengoku as the mastermind behind the psychological warfare strategy that led to Squard's betrayal. He acknowledges the Marines' tactical brilliance.
events.significance: Demonstrates Whitebeard's tactical understanding and gives credit to Sengoku's strategic mind, showing the chess game being played at the highest levels of the war.

quotes.text: Well done, Sengoku. A brilliant strategy.
quotes.speaker: Whitebeard
quotes.context: Whitebeard acknowledges the Fleet Admiral's deceptive plan

events.title: Aokiji Freezes Buggy to Stop Broadcast
events.description: Admiral Aokiji uses his ice powers to freeze Buggy and his allies who have been broadcasting the battle to the world, attempting to cut off the world's view of the war.
events.significance: The Marines attempt to control the narrative by stopping the broadcast of the battle, though this doesn't completely succeed.

events.title: Whitebeard Creates Escape Route
events.description: To prove he hasn't betrayed his allies, Whitebeard uses his Gura Gura no Mi (Tremor-Tremor Fruit) powers to shatter the ice walls that the Marines created to trap the pirates. This creates an escape route for the allied pirate fleet.
events.significance: Whitebeard demonstrates his power and commitment to his allies, rallying the pirate forces and disproving Akainu's lies about betrayal. This reinvigorates the allied pirates' morale.

events.title: Whitebeard Rallies His Forces
events.description: After proving his loyalty by creating escape routes, Whitebeard rallies all his pirates and allied crews. He makes it clear that he will not abandon Ace and urges his forces to continue fighting.
events.significance: This moment restores the pirates' morale and demonstrates Whitebeard's leadership. It counters the psychological damage of Akainu's manipulation.

events.title: Philosophy of Family Over Blood
events.description: Whitebeard's actions and words throughout the episode emphasize his philosophy that family is defined by bonds and loyalty, not blood. He forgives Squard and defends Ace, showing that he values every person as an individual.
events.significance: This episode encapsulates one of One Piece's core themes: chosen family and the bonds we create matter more than bloodlines or parentage.

themes.description: The episode powerfully demonstrates Whitebeard's unconditional love for his 'sons' through his forgiveness of Squard despite the betrayal and stabbing.
themes.symbolism: Whitebeard's embrace of Squard symbolizes true parental love that forgives even the deepest wounds.

themes.description: Akainu's successful manipulation of Squard shows how psychological tactics can be more effective than physical combat in warfare.
themes.symbolism: The sword thrust represents how lies and deception can wound even the strongest individuals.

themes.description: Whitebeard's declaration that children shouldn't bear their parents' sins and his treatment of all pirates as his sons regardless of lineage emphasizes chosen family over blood relations.
themes.symbolism: Whitebeard's crew structure mirrors a family where the father loves all children equally.

themes.description: Despite being wounded and betrayed, Whitebeard rallies his forces and proves his loyalty, demonstrating true leadership.
themes.symbolism: Breaking the ice walls symbolizes breaking through doubt and restoring faith.

characterSpotlights.role: Central protagonist demonstrating leadership and forgiveness
characterSpotlights.development: Whitebeard's character reaches an emotional peak as he demonstrates unconditional love, tactical awareness, and unwavering commitment to his family despite being stabbed.

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime expanded Squard's backstory and his relationship with Whitebeard through additional flashback scenes not present in the manga.
The emotional beats of Whitebeard's forgiveness were given more screen time and emphasis in the anime adaptation.

trivia.fact: This episode is based on Chapter 563 of the manga, titled 'One Man, One Heart.'
Episode 472 received an IMDb rating of 9.3/10, making it one of the highest-rated episodes of the Marineford Arc.

sources.title: One Piece - Akainu no Bouryaku! Otoshiirerareta Shirohige

trivia.fact: The episode aired in the US one day before it aired in Japan due to Funimation's simulcast schedule.
Seiji Sasaki, who voices Squard, also voices Blueno and other One Piece characters.
